title-group.article-title: Microstructural characterization and wear properties of ultra-dispersed nanodiamond (UDD) reinforced Al matrix composites fabricated by ball-milling and sintering

article-meta.aff: 1Advanced Technology Education, Research and Application Center, Mersin University, Ciftlikkoy Campus, 33343, Mersin, Turkey
2Particulate Materials Laboratories, Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Istanbul Technical University, Maslak 34469, Istanbul, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: H Kaftelen, Advanced Technology Education, Research and Application Center, Mersin University, Ciftlikkoy Campus, 33343, Mersin, Turkey Email: hkafdelen@mersin.edu.tr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Elemental aluminum (Al) powders reinforced with 1–10 wt% of ultra-dispersed nanodiamond (UDD) powders were ball-milled in a SpexTM Mixer/Mill between 0 and 120 min followed by consolidation and sintering. X-ray diffraction analyses on the ball-milled powders revealed only α-Al peaks, whereas Al4C3 phase was identified along with α-Al in all sintered composites. Increasing the addition of nanodiamond to Al-matrix resulted in improved hardness of both ball-milled and sintered composites. The wear resistances of the Al-UDD composites were significantly improved with increasing UDD contents. Under similar load and sliding conditions, the wear resistance of Al matrix composite containing 10 wt% nanodiamond enhances about 40 times when compared with unreinforced aluminum.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: High-energy ball milling is a powder processing method that produces nanocrystalline/or amorphous structures and nanocomposite powder particles of the desired alloy composition.1–3 On a microscopic scale, this process involves repeated high-energy collisions, cold welding, and fracture of powder materials during grinding in high-energy ball mills.4 This process has received much attention as a powerful method for the fabrication ofceramic particle (such as SiC, Al2O3, B4C, TiC)-reinforced aluminum (Al) composites5,6 because of much better mechanical properties of these composites than those fabricated by casting methods, especially for higher temperature applications.7

Among the commonly used reinforcing particles, the diamond nanopowders have become new engineering materials with possible applications in many fields8 such as thermal management, cutting tools, wear resistance coatings, optics, and electronic devices9 because of their contributions to better mechanical,10 physical, electrical,11 and optical12 properties. Up to now, a number of studies have been performed on nanodiamond as potential nanoadditives for Cu,13 Cu-Sn,14 polymer matrix such as polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE),15 and as coating materials for Cu,16 Ni-matrix, and Fe-matrix17 in order to improve their friction and wear properties. However, limited investigations have been carried out on the production of nanodiamond particle-reinforced Al-based matrix composites for the purpose of improving friction and wear properties18–20 and thermal properties of composites.21 Hanada et al.19 compared the friction and wear properties of nanodiamond dispersed Al-Si-Cu-Mg composite with two kinds of detonation nanodiamonds, namely as-synthesized and purified detonation nanodiamonds, using high-energy ball milling. They reported that the composites containing 1 vol.% diamond nanoclusters reduce the friction coefficient and wear loss of the composites dueto the rolling effect. The similar observation wasalso reported by Quyang and Okada.18 Except the polymer-based composites, only a small amount of nanodiamond (1 vol.%) particles have been used in some of these investigations13,18,19 in order to avoid increased agglomeration of nanodiamond powders. Inthe study of Livramento et al.,22 a homogeneous distribution of nanodiamond particles with high fractions in the range of 10–30 at.% was achieved for Cumatrix using ball milling. However, these powders were not sintered for further microstructural characterizations, physical and wear property evaluations of composites. Currently, there exist no comprehensive studies including the powder and the sinter characterizations of UDD-reinforced Al composites. Therefore, the main objective of this experimental research is to analyze the effect of both ball-milling time and content of nanodiamond particles on the microstructure, hardness, density, and wear properties of Al matrix composites.

sec.title: Material preparation
sec.p:
In this investigation, Al (Alfa Aesar, >99.7% purity, particle size ∼10 µm) and ultra-dispersed nanodiamond (UDD; up to 99.5% pure diamond, 2–50 nm) powders were used as starting materials. Technical specifications of the UDD powders, supplied by ALIT Co. from Ukraine produced using detonation technique are listed in Table 123 and the structure of UDD powders are given in Figure 1. X-ray diffraction (XRD) peaks of nanodiamond powders resulting from (111), (220), and (311) reflection planes at 2θ = 43.9°, 75.02°, and 91.1°, respectively, are illustrated in Figure 1(a), while Figure1(b) is a representative scanning electron microscope (SEM) micrograph of the UDD powders. XRD peaks are broad and wide owing to very small average crystallite size of UDD powders. Prior to ball-milling experiments, all powder batches were mixed for 3 h in a LaborTM turbula shaker mixer. For ball-milling experiments, a powder batch weighing total 8 g of Al powders containing 1%, 5%, and 10 wt.% UDD (now hereafter referred to as Al-1UDD, Al-5UDD, and Al-10UDD, respectively) were sealed in a hardened steel vial in a glovebox filled with argon atmosphere to prevent oxidation. Zinc stearate (2 wt.%) was used as a process control agent to retard excessive cold welding during the ball-milling process. Ball-milling was carried out for 0, 30, 60, 90, and 120 min in a high-energy Spex 8000DTM Mixer/Mill using 6.36 mm stainless steel ballsas grinding media. A ball to powder weight ratio of 7 : 1 was used. The mechanically alloyed powders werelater cold-pressed uniaxially using a constant pressure of 700 MPa in a steel mold to form a 12 mm cylindrical compact. The compacts were degassed at 430°C for 1 h and then sintered at 640°C24 for 10 h in a LinnTM furnace under flowing argon gas condition. Theblended pure Al powders were also consolidated and sintered in order to compare the effects of nanodiamond on theproperties of Al and resulting microstructures. The consolidatedand sintered composites were analyzed in terms of microstructure, density, hardness, and wear properties. Table 1.
Technical specifications of ultra-dispersed diamond (UDD) powders used in the present work23
Particle size 2–50 nm
Pynometric density 3.2 g/cm3
Initial air oxidation behavior 430°C
Initial vacuum graphitization behavior 1100–1200°C
Bulk weight 0.4–0.6 g/cm3
Figure 1.
(a) X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns and (b) the scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of the ultra-dispersed ultra-dispersed nanodiamond (UDD) powders.

sec.title: Characterization studies
sec.p: XRD investigations of both mechanical alloyed powders and the sintered samples were carried out using a BrukerTM 8D advance instrument with a standard CuKα radiation source employing a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. Cold mounted milled powders and hot mounted sectioned sintered samples were ground manually using 400, 600, 800, and 1200 grit SiC paper. After grinding, the alloyed powders and sintered samples were polished using 0.5 µm Al2O3 using soft cloth prior to the XRD measurements. Thermal analyses were performed in TATM differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) instruments. Samples of ∼7 mg contained in α-alumina crucible were heated up to 650°C with a heating rate of 20°C/min. During the heating process, a stream of Ar and H2 gases was introduced into the furnace at a flow rate of 30 mL/min and 5 mL/min, respectively. The particle size measurements of ball-milled powders were conducted using a MalvernTM laser particle size analyzer. Powders were dispersed in distilled water using an ultrasonic bath to prevent powder agglomeration and a surfactant was added into the powder slurry.

Microstructural and morphological investigations were conducted using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) JEOLTM JSM 7000 F operating at a voltage of 15 kV equipped with an IXRFTM energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). Prior to SEM investigations, polished samples were etched using Keller’s reagent for 30 s. The specific surface areas (SAs) of ball-milled powders were measured by nitrogen adsorption at liquid nitrogen temperature using a QuantachromeTM Autosorb 1C apparatus. Before analysis, the milled samples were outgassed in helium for 12 h at 150°C. The sorption isotherms (quantity of argon adsorbed onto the sample surface at various pressures) were measured at 77 K and particle SA measurements were done using the Barret, Joyner, and Halenda (BJH) method.25

Hardness measurements of sintered samples were obtained using a Shimadzu™ hardness tester under a load of 50 g for 15 s. Average hardness values with standard deviations were determined from 15 impressions of the sintered samples. The bulk densities of sintered samples were measured according to the Archimedes’ method26 in ethanol as an immersion medium. In addition, a relative density for each sample was determined by using the density ratio of Archimedes density divided by the theoretical density which was calculated using the rule of mixtures.27

Wear properties were investigated using a TribotechnicTM dry sliding reciprocating wear instrument by rubbing 1.587 µm steel balls (100 CR6-62 HRC) on the surfaces of the samples. A load of 1 N at normal atmospheric conditions (23°C and at about 50% relative humidity), a sliding velocity 10 mm/s, and a total sliding distance of 5 m were applied. Before wear test, each specimen was ground and polished to make sure that the wear surface was in complete contact with the surface of the steel ball (ISO 3290). The worn surfaces were examined by the SEM. Results of the wear tests were evaluated according to the volume of the material loss measured by a profilometer (MahrTM Perhen S&P PerthometerTM).

sec.title: Powder characterization
sec.p:
A quantitative information on the ball-milling behavior of powders can be obtained from the particle size distribution analysis. Figure 2(a)–(c) shows the influence of increasing milling times on the particle size distribution results of the Al-1UDD, Al-5UDD, and Al-10UDD powders, respectively. For each composition, the particle size distributions shift significantly to the larger particle size values with the ball-milling time indicating the agglomeration of powders. Furthermore, increasing theball-milling time resulted in the narrower particle size distributions in each powder sample, in Figure 2. In the case of Al-5UDD and Al-10UDD, as the milling time increases, the shape of particle size distribution changed from a mono-modal type to a bi-modal one, while Al-1UDD composite powders have a mono-modal type particle size distribution with ball-milling time. Therefore, it can be suggested that the amount of UDD particle in Al powders affect the shape of particle size distribution with increasing ball-milling time. When particle sizes of initial powders are significantly different,28 Al-UDD powders tend to strongly agglomerate with increasing ball-milling durations due to the large SA of UDD particles. Furthermore, the increase in themean particle size (D50) of powders with ball-milling time indicates a strong interparticle bonding (physical) in the agglomerates. Figure 2.
Particle size distributions of (a) Al-1UDD, (b) Al-5UDD, and (c) Al-10UDD powders ball-milled for 30, 60, 90, and 120 min.

The effect of agglomeration with ball-milling durations can also be observed by the specific SA measurements performed on Al-1UDD, Al-5UDD, and Al-10UDD composite powders ball-milled for 30, 60, 90, and 120 min. The values of specific SA and the mean particle size, D50 (taken as the 50% size of thecumulative particle size distribution), of composite powders as a function of both ball-milling time and UDD content are given in Table 2. The SA of ball-milled powders decreases with increasing ball-milling time due to agglomeration of Al-UDD powders during ball-milling process. For each ball-milling time, SA of powders increases substantially with increasing UDD contents due to the high SA of the UDD powders (i.e., measured as about 277 m2/g). The SA results of composite powders after milling for 30 min increased from a value of 5.25 m2/g for the Al-1UDD to 18.57 m2/g for the Al-10UDD composite powders. Table 2.
Variations in the specific surface area (SA) and the mean particle size (D50) of composite powders as a function of ball-milling time
Results for a given ball-milling time/min
30 60 90 120
D50 (µm) SA (m2/g) D50 (µm) SA (m2/g) D50 (µm) SA (m2/g) D50 (µm) SA (m2/g)
Al-1UDD 13.7 5.25 53.2 2.82 82.5 1.46 97.7 1.33
Al-5UDD 13.2 9.77 17.2 5.45 53.0 1.48 66.5 1.11
Al-10UDD 9.85 18.57 12.7 7.12 19.9 2.81 25.9 2.01

Figure 3(a)–(e) shows the morphological changes of the as-blended Al-5UDD powders and those ball-milled for 30, 60, 90, and 120 min, respectively. It should be noted here that similar powder morphologies as a function of ball-milling time were also observed for theAl-1UDD and Al-10UDD composite powders. Asshown in Figure 3(a), as-blended Al-5UDD powder particles, mixed for 3 h using a turbula mixer, are mostly elongated and irregular in shape and have a narrow size distribution. As revealed in Figure 3(b), the Al-5UDD powder particles were initially plastically deformed in the early stages of ball-milling resulting in flakes between irregular particles. When the ball-milling duration was increased to 60 min, mostly sharp-cornered powder morphologies were observed (Figure 3(c)). Afterward, particle agglomerates consisting of particles having 2 µm average sizes are noticeable in the SEM micrographs of the Al-5UDD composites ball-milled for 90 min (Figure 3(d)) and 120 min (Figure 3(e)). Such behavior indicates that flake-like particles were cold welded to form larger particles which were maintained after 60 min of ball-milling time. Although mechanical alloying time increases from 90 to 120 min, no significant particle size refinement and morphological changes were obtained. This is likely due to the presence of the strong physical bonding between the fine particles in the agglomerates.29 Figure 3.
Scanning electron microscope (SEM) morphology of Al-5UDD composite powders in the (a) as-blended condition, and after ball-milled for (b) 30, (c) 60, (d) 90, and (e) 120 min.

Figure 4(a)–(d) is the XRD patterns of the Al-10UDD powders in the as-blended state and these ball-milled for 30, 90, and 120 min, respectively. Asseen in Figure 4(a), in the case of as-blended powders, sharp diffraction peaks indicate the presence of coarse crystalline grains in the elemental Al and UDD particles. Remarkably, the XRD patterns of ball-milled Al-10UDD powders (Figure 4(b)–(d)) exhibit only the reflections of the Al matrix inferring either no carbide formation or any carbide formation during ball-milling not to be detectable. All major detectable peaks in Figure 4(a)–(d) belongs to the cubic α-Al phase with the lattice parameter a = 0.40494 nm and space group Fm3m.30 It is believed that the nanodiamond grains are too small to be detected using the XRD technique. Furthermore, a slight broadening of peaks and diminishing of their intensities with ball-milling are due to decrease in the average Al crystallite size of powders and increase in the lattice strain content. This was explained by the continuous deformation and work hardening of powders during ball-milling process.31 The change in crystallite size with the increase in ball-milling time was determined by analyzing the broadening of the (111) Al peak, based on the Scherrer equation.1 In order to eliminate the instrumental contribution, peak width at half maximum (FWHM) determined from a well-annealed sample (300°C, 3 h) was subtracted from the observed peak width caused by ball-milling. The average grain sizes of the Al-10UDD composite were calculated approximately as 804, 416, and 259 nm for 30, 90, and 120 min of ball-milling times, respectively. This indicates that the average grain size in Al-10UDD composite powder decreased with increasing ball-milling times due to severe plastic deformation during milling process. Figure 4.
X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Al-10UDD powders (a) in the as-blended condition and after ball-milled for (b) 30 (c) 90 and (d) 120 min.

As the ductile metal particles undergo severe plastic deformation, fracturing of particles create clean metalsurfaces. Where the powder particles overlap, metallurgical bonds are formed leading to particle growth and the formation of composite particles. Asball-milling process continues, the internal structure of the powders continues to be refined.7 In addition to this, reinforcement phase enhances the hardness values of powders. Hence, the hardness values of Al-1UDD, Al-5UDD, and Al-10UDD powder particles can change during mechanical alloying, which are given in Figure 5. Figure 5 shows that the hardness of all Al-UDD powders increases up to 90 min of ball-milling time and slightly decreases after this time. Considering hardness plots shown in Figure 5(a)–(c), it can also be suggested that ball-milling process has a more profound effect on the hardness of powders compared to that of the reinforcement phase. For example, the Al-10UDD powders ball-milled for 120 min are almost two timesharder than the same ball-milled for 30 min (Figure 5(c)). An increment in hardness of milled powders was observed due to work hardening during ball-milling. For all ball-milled powder composites, decrease in hardness values beyond 90 min of ball-milling time suggests that the tendency for cold welding predominates over fracturing after 90 min of ball-milling time. On the other hand, the strain energy accumulates during ball-milling and reaches a maximum value at this stage.1 The maximum hardness value was measured as1.4 GPa for the Al-10UDD powders after ball-milling for 90 min. Therefore, in the present study, the Al-1UDD, Al-5UDD and Al-10UDD powders ball-milled for 90 min and the Al-5UDD powders ball milled for 30, 60, 90, and 120 min were sintered in order to investigate both the effect of UDD content and ball-milling time. Similar decrease in the hardness of powders (Figure 5) after a certain ball-milling time was also observed in the study of Bhaduri et al.32 This behavior was explained by recovery and/or recrystallization phenomena which occur due to temperature increases (between 100°C and 200°C)1 during ball-milling. Examples of powder hardness increases during ball-milling of AA2014 powders containing carbide reinforcements (TiC, VC) have also been reported by Ruiz-Navas et al.7 Figure 5.
Hardness versus ball-milling time for the: (a) Al-1UDD, (b) Al-5UDD, and (c) Al-10UDD composite powders.

sec.title: Microstructure and thermal characterization during sintering
sec.p:
XRD investigations have been carried out to characterize the phases present in the sintered Al-1UDD, Al-5UDD, and Al-10UDD composites prepared from powders ball-milled for 90 min. Figure 6 shows the X-ray patterns of the composites sintered at 630°C for 10 h under Ar atmosphere. As identified by the XRD analysis, in addition to the matrix α-Al phase,30 the Al4C3 phase (Bravais lattice; rhombohedral, Space group: R3¯m (166), a = 0.33 nm, b = 0.249 nm)33 is present and neither diamond nor diamond-related phases are detected in all sintered composites. The increase of volume fraction of the Al4C3 phase with increasing UDD powder content is evidenced by its peak intensity in the XRD patterns. Apparently, some UDD particles lost their integrity and were chemically decomposed into graphite which reacted with α-Al to form the Al4C3 phase during sintering. As reported in several studies,21,34,35 formation of Al4C3 phase might be due to high specific SA (277 m2/g) of nanodiamond powders, which are susceptible to decomposition into graphite or graphite-like phases upon thermal exposure in inert atmospheres or ultra-high vacuum at temperatures above 1500°C. Xu et al.8 also investigated the thermal stability behavior of nanodiamonds (synthesized from graphite by explosion) under both argon and oxygen atmospheres and they reported that graphitization starts at 670°C. Owing to severe deformation induced by ball milling, the decomposition of the nanodiamond powders leading to Al4C3 formation in the microstructure of Al-UDD composites was achieved at the sintering temperature of 630°C, which is lower than graphitization temperature of UDD powders.8 Figure 6.
X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Al-UDD composites ball-milled for 90 min followed by sintering at 630°C:(a) Al-1UDD, (b) Al-5UDD, and (c) Al-10UDD.

The microstuctural details of the sintered Al-5UDD and Al-10UDD composites ball-milled for 90 min are shown in SEM micrographs given in Figure 7(a) and (b), respectively. Fine strings represent Al4C3 phases (as indicated by an arrow) in the Al matrix containing 5 wt.% nanodiamond (Figure 7(a)) while Al4C3 appears as a clear dark phase in the microstructure of the Al-10UDD composite (Figure 7(b)). SEM images also verify the formation ofAl4C3 phases in α-Al matrix after sintering at the temperature of 630°C. It can be seen clearly that some porosities were nucleated near the carbide particles on grain boundaries where high stress concentrations can develop. Figure 7.
Scanning electron microscope (SEM) micrographs of sintered samples ball-milled for 90 min (a) Al-5UDD and (b) Al-10UDD.

The heat released measured by DSC during the heating of ball-milled particles is used to obtain useful information in the evolution of the reactions in solid-state during sintering. In this study, DSC analyses were performed to reveal the structural changes of the ball-milled Al-10UDD powders in the heating process. DSC traces of the Al-10UDD powders after ball-milling at different times are given in Figure 8. The DSC curves of the Al-10UDD powders ball-milled at different durations (30, 60, 90, and 120 min.) display one endothermic peak at about 80°C, due to dehydration and\or decomposition of the process control agent (i.e.zinc stearate for the present work). For the Al-10UDD powders ball-milled for 90 min and 120 min, the areas of this endothermic peak became smaller (Figure 8(c) and 8(d)). This means that the amount of free surfactant decreases after 90 min of ball-milling time. It was noted36 in a previous work that for a heating rate of 20°C/min, the thermal decomposition of zinc stearate occurred at 128°C corresponding to its melting point. However, in this study, small endothermic peaks observed in the vicinity of 80°C probably correspond to the melting of zinc stearate whose equilibrium melting point decreased due to ball-milling. After ball-milling Al-10UDD powders for 90 and 120 min, sharp exothermic peaks emerged respectively at 603°C and 611°C in the DSC scans, while the same powders ball-milled for 30 and 60 min have low intensity and broad exothermic peaks. These exothermic peaks are likely due to the formation of Al4C3 by a reaction between Al and nanodiamond. A similar exothermic peak was observed in a characterization study on the milled Al/C composite.37 It can be suggested that all elemental phases (i.e., Al and C) react with each other after a certain milling time with temperature. When the ball-milling time increases from 60 to 90 and 120 min, high defect densities induced in the milling lead to large reaction interface areas between Al and UDD particles and shorten the diffusion distances to enable the formation of the Al4C3 phase. The exothermic peak temperature slightly increases from about 600 to 611°C when the milling time increases from 90 min to 120 min, and the peak becomes sharper (Figure 8(c) and 8(d)). Such observations have been reported by Wu et al.38 for the Al-C system ball milled for 40 h using a planetary ball mill. Figure 8.
Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) scan curves of Al-10UDD powders ball-milled for (a) 30, (b) 60, (c) 90, and (d)120 min.

To reveal phase formations/transformations associated with the exothermic peak shown on the DSC thermogram of the Al-10UDD powders ball-milled for 90 min (Figure 8(c)), XRD analyses were performed on these powders annealed at 570°C (just above the onset temperature of exothermic peak in Figure 8(c)) and at 650°C (above the peak temperature of the exothermic peak in Figure 8(c)). Figure 9(a) and (b) are the XRD patterns of the Al-10UDD powders ball-milled for 90 min and annealed at 570°C and 650°C, respectively. It is evident from Figure 9 that only matrix α-Al peaks are present and no carbide formation is observed at 570°C, whereas the Al4C3 peaks are formed in addition to the matrix α-Al peaks at 650°C. This confirms that the exothermic peaks shown in Figure 8(c) and (d) correspond to the Al4C3 phase formed as a result of a reaction between Al and UDD powders. Similar DSC curves were also obtained for the Al-1UDD and Al-5UDD composite powders ball-milled for 90 min and for longer times. Figure 9.
X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Al-10UDD powders ball-milled for 90 min and annealed at: (a) 570°C and (b) 650°C.

sec.title: Density, hardness, and wear properties of sintered samples
sec.p:
Using the rule of mixtures, the theoretical density values for each composite were calculated as: ρT=2.62g/cm3 for the Al-1UDD composites, ρT=2.64g/cm3 for Al-5UDD composites and ρT=2.66g/cm3 for Al-10UDD composites. Figure 10 shows the relative densities of the Al-5UDD samples as a function of ball-milling time and the UDD content. The relative density value of pure Al (ball milled for 90 min) is also presented in this figure to observe the effect of reinforcement. The sintered density depends on the milling time as well as the UDD content. Clearly, the relative density values increase with increasing UDD contents and reach a value of 95(%) for both the Al-5UDD and the Al-10UDD composites ball-milled for 90 min. The Al-5UDD composite sample prepared from powders ball-milled for 30 min showed the maximum relative density, over 98%, whereas this value reduced gradually with increasing ball-milling times. It is generally expected that the increase in ball-milling time leads to fine powder sizes which provide short diffusion distances between the constituents, and which enhance the densification during sintering. However, in the present study, in spite of increasing ball-milling time, the agglomeration of Al-5UDD powders (Figure 3) considerably increased which made sintering more difficult. From this point of view, ball-milling time leads to a decrease in density of the Al-5UDD composite with extent of milling. However, homogeneously distributed reinforcement particles within a refined microstructure are desirable to improve the mechanical properties such as strength, elastic modulus, and wear resistance.39 Poor mechanical properties owing to the agglomeration of nanodiamond particles (5–30 at.%) in Cu composite were reported by Hanada et. al.,13 although a high densification after fabrication via ball-milling following spark plasma sintering was obtained in the same study. Therefore, it can be concluded that aggregated nanodiamond particles were not dissociated and ball-milling did not effectively break down the agglomerates. Figure 10.
Variation of relative density of the sintered composites as a function of ball-milling time and ultra-dispersed nanodiamond (UDD) content.

Variations of wear resistance as a function of both nanodiamond content in Al matrix (i.e., sintered Al-1UDD, Al-5UDD, and Al-10UDD composites prepared from the 90 min of ball-milled powders) and ball-milling time (30, 60, 90, and 120 min) for the sintered Al-5UDD composites are examined in Figure 11. As expected, the hardness values increase linearly with increasing weight fraction of UDD in the Al matrix, thatis, a maximum value of about 3 GPa is achieved for the Al-10UDD composite while the hardness value of the pure Al is 0.5 GPa (Figure 11(a)). The increase in hardness can be attributed to the incorporation of UDD particles with increasing content as well as the presence of hard Al4C3 phase particles formed during sintering. Hard particulate reinforcements act as barriers to dislocation movement within the matrix and exhibit greater resistance to indentation of the hardness tester.40 Thehardness values of the Al-10UDD composites are comparable to those of Al-based matrix composites reinforced with different secondary particles having similar fractions, 10 wt.%, that is, 1.03 GPa with SiC.41 Figure 11(b) shows the dependence of wear resistance on the hardness of sintered Al-5UDD composites prepared from the powders ball-milled for 0, 30, 60, 90, and 120 min. It is obvious that sintered hardness values increase with increases in ball-milling time up to 90 min. No substantial differences between the hardness results of the Al-5UDD composites prepared after ball-milling for 60, 90, and 120 min were observed, and the sintered hardness values were between 1.66 and 1.83 GPa. Figure 11.
Variation of wear resistance of sintered samples with hardness as a function of: (a) ultra-dispersed nanodiamond (UDD) content, (b) ball-milling time. Note the symbol (•) in the graph (b) belonging to as-blended Al-5UDD composite sample.

In this study, relative wear resistance of the samples was quantified by dividing the wear track area of the sintered unreinforced Al to that of composites. Thus, wear resistance of the unreinforced Al was taken as 1. As seen in Figure 11(a), the wear resistance of the Al-UDD composites increases with increasing content of reinforcement particles. Increasing the content of UDD particles from 0 wt.% through 10 wt.%, the wear resistance increased approximately by 40 times (Figure 11(a)), whereas about sixfold higher resistance was achieved in the wear of the Al-5UDD composite after 30 min of ball milling than the unmilled Al-5UDD sintered composite (Figure 11(b)). For the case of the sintered Al-5UDD composite, increased hardness and ball-milling times have a little contribution to the wear resistance of the composites (Figure 11(b)). Therefore, it can be suggested that the increased UDD content and ball-milling times are attributable to the increase of hardness and good wear resistance.

Figure 12(a) and 12(b) shows the variation of friction coefficient, μ, as a function of the UDD content and ball-milling time for the sintered unreinforced Al and the sintered Al-UDD composites, respectively. The coefficient of friction decreases rapidly with the addition of UDD particles, as evident from Figure 12(a). Al-10UDD composite has the lowest coefficient of friction of 0.33, while sintered unreinforced Al exhibited an average coefficient of friction of 0.75. The friction coefficients of Al-1UDD and Al-5UDD are around 0.4 whereas slightly lower friction coefficient (0.33) is observed forthe Al-10UDD composite, despite the fact that a significant decrease in friction coefficient with increasing content of UDD is to be expected. Therefore, it is believed that friction coefficient values decrease probably due to higher UDD contents and oxides built up on the sliding surface of the Al-10UDD composite. Recently, Hanada and Sano42 studied the friction and wear behavior of an Al-Si-based composites reinforced with detonation nanodiamonds under a sliding load of 0.2 N and a sliding speed of 0.5 mm/s. Their results showed that the friction coefficient of the Al-Si-based matrix alloy reduced from 0.36 to 0.14 with the addition of 1 vol.% of nanodiamond particles. It was notified that39,43,44 the volume fraction of reinforcement has the strongest effect on the wear and friction performance of reinforced Al composites in addition to the type and size of the reinforcement. It is clear from Figure 12(b) that friction coefficient (µ) is nearly independent of the milling time for the Al-5UDD composite, although a slightly high µ value was obtained in the composite ball-milled for 60 min compared to those ones milled for 90 and 120 min. It can be suggested that a little high hardness value of the composite ball-milled for 60 min (Figure 11(b)) has an effect on the reduction of the friction coefficient. Thus, it can be stated that the incorporation of UDD into the Al-matrix leads to an improvement in the friction behavior of composites. Similarly, Quang and Okada18 reported that friction coefficient decreased very rapidly with the addition of 10 wt.% diamond clusters to Al and it remained constant for the Al containing 10–50 wt.% diamond clusters. They reported that excellent lubricating ability of ultrafine particles during the sliding friction process could provide low friction and good wear resistances to the Al-diamond composites. Figure 12.
Variation of friction coefficient with (a) ultra-dispersed nanodiamond (UDD) content, (b) ball-milling time for the Al-5UDD sintered composite samples.

SEM investigations were carried out on the worn surfaces of sintered composites in order to determine the effective wear mechanism. Figure 13(a) and (b) is typical worn surface appearances of Al-5UDD and Al-10UDD composites, respectively. The presence of rougher and deeper grooves parallel to the sliding direction in the microstructure of the Al-5UDD composite indicates that extensive plastic deformation associated with adhesive damage took place (Figure 13(a)). The worn surface appearance of the Al-10UDD composite (Figure 13(b)) is quite different from the Al-5UDD composite sample. As seen in Figure 13(b), smooth worn surfaces without large grooves and small amounts of spalling can be observed in the Al-10UDD composite. This is because both high hardness (3.3 GPa) and high UDD content enable the Al-10UDD composite to resist destructive action of the counterface (steel ball) during wear tests. On the basis of the corresponding EDS analysis taken from the region marked as A given in Figure 13(c) indicates that the mid-gray regions are belonging to the Al-rich areas with some transferred Fe from the steel counterface. Besides, the high amount of oxygen content detected in the EDS analysis from the frictional heating during the sliding wear. It was reported that45 this oxide layer includes very fine, crystalline oxide particles, which have been compacted onto the surface of the composite, preexisting surface oxide layers, or compressed coarse wear debris. In addition, presence of large amount of fine particles on the worn surfaces of Al-10UDD composite is characterized by the oxidative wear. Furthermore, the decrease in friction coefficient of the Al-10UDD composite can be attributed to the development of an oxide layer, which acts as a lubricant, on the worn surface,46 providing a protective layer preventing metallic contact and lowering wear rate. These kind of worn surface characterizationswere reported in several investigations on the dry sliding wear of metal matrix composites.47–49 Figure 13.
Scanning electron microscope (SEM) micrographs of inner region of wear tracks of the (a) Al-5UDD composite ball milled for 60 min, (b) Al-10UDD composite ball-milled for 90 min, and (c) corresponding energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) analysis taken from region A.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In the present study, three different Al-UDD composites were fabricated from Al powders reinforced with 1 wt.%, 5 wt.%, and 10 wt.% of UDD particles via ball-milling and sintering. Microstructural, thermal, physical, hardness, and wear properties of these composites were investigated. On the basis of the results reported in the present investigation, the following conclusions can be drawn:
With increasing milling times, the average particle size of ball-milled Al-UDD powders increases with increasing milling time due to powder agglomeration. Their hardness increases with the UDD content and with increasing ball-milling times up to 90 min.
XRD investigations revealed only α-Al peaks in ball-milled Al-UDD powders and peaks belonging to α-Al and Al4C3 phases in all sintered Al-UDD composites. DSC and XRD analyses verified that the Al4C3 phase forms approximately between 600°C and 615°C in the microstructure of Al-UDD composites.
Increasing the UDD content improves hardness and wear properties of the sintered Al-UDD composites. A maximum hardness value of 3 GPa was measured for the Al-10UDD composite which is six times higher than that of pure Al. The wear resistance of the sintered Al-10UDD composite is 40 times better than unreinforced sintered Al.
The friction coefficient values decrease with the incorporation and increase of UDD contents in the sintered Al-UDD composites, however ball-milling durations have no significant effect on the friction coefficient of the composites.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: This research is financially supported by State Planning Organization (DPT) of Turkey under the Project Title ‘Development of Al and Cu Based Metal Matrix Composites Using Mechanical Alloying Techniques’ with the project number 90189 and this is gratefully acknowledged. The authors wish to thank Professor Hüseyin Çimenoğlu for his valuable comments and discussions on the wear results of this study. The authors are thankful to Mr. Talat Tamer Alpak for helping during the SEM investigations and Mr. Mert Günyüz for his help during the wear experiments.
